body: Woohoo!
This can't possibly be on by default, right? It doubles the runtime of the already slow js test suite, and is almost entirely redundant.

This feels a bit like nitpicking since it doesn't sound like this is ready for merge, but since you've made a pull request: I don't think test groups is quite the right way to do this. A test group is a set of unique tests, and it breaks the mental model if different test groups start to mean the same tests run in different environments. I'd rather treat this like different versions of Python: the environments to test are specified by an external tool like Tox or Travis.
Agreed with @takluyver. Both casper and slimer should not be included in the same run. It should be a switch based on the environment (either ENV variable or flag to iptest or both).

>  It should be a switch based on the environment (either ENV variable or flag to iptest or both).

This is how it behaves right now, unless you have both installed on your machine, then it uses both.  Maybe instead of using both in this case, it should just use phantomjs.  What do you guys think?

>  unless you have both installed on your machine, then it uses both. 

It should never use both. Using both should require two runs of iptest with different arguments.

> It should never use both. Using both should require two runs of iptest with different arguments.

I've just changed it so it defaults to casperjs and only uses slimmerjs if casperjs isn't found or the "slimerjs" command line flag is used.
Makes sense thanks.
When this goes in, it'll be possible to resurrect #4560

Other than my inline comments, fair warning that I spent a day trying to get our then much less thorough test suite passing with slimerjs, and did not succeed and gave up. Perhaps that situation has changed. (I did not try to employ `xvfb` and just ended up with dozens of Firefox windows, but @jdfreder should at least know about `xvfb` because it'll be required to run slimer on Travis)

> Other than my inline comments, fair warning that I spent a day trying to get our then much less thorough test suite passing with slimerjs, and did not succeed and gave up. Perhaps that situation has changed. (I did not try to employ xvfb and just ended up with dozens of Firefox windows, but @jdfreder should at least know about xvfb because it'll be required to run slimer on Travis)

Thanks for the heads up @ivanov .  There are quite a few failures, but not a horrendous amount.  I'm willing to spend more than a day on it, after 2.0 is released.  Also, thanks for the heads up about xvfb.
https://github.com/laurentj/slimerjs/issues/80

OK!  So CasperJS + SlimerJS is finally running in Travis! (see the last commit).  One caveat, SlimerJS doesn't allow exit return codes (and probably never will), consequently iptest sees CaperJS + SlimerJS test failures as passes.  I'm going to have to parse the stdout to see if it has any lines that start with 'FAIL'.
I cherry picked #5391 into this.

Woohoo!  Entire test suite now passes for both Slimer and Phantom on Travis!  Cool!

I still should tidy things up in the code before we do anything with this PR...

In my last commit I reverted the Travis yaml changes.  I've also squashed a bunch of unnecessary iterative commits.

Just in case someone decides to add SlimerJS support to Travis in the furture, this is what was required:

``` yml
# http://travis-ci.org/#!/ipython/ipython
language: python
python:
    - 2.7
    - 3.3
addons:
    firefox: "26.0"
env:
    - FULL;
    - SLIMERJS; IPTEST_ARGS='js --slimerjs'; SLIMERJSLAUNCHER=$(which firefox); DISPLAY=:99.0; PATH=$TRAVIS_BUILD_DIR/slimerjs:$PATH; export PATH;
before_install:
    # Workaround for https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-cookbooks/issues/155
    - sudo rm -rf /dev/shm && sudo ln -s /run/shm /dev/shm
    - easy_install -q pyzmq
    - pip install jinja2 sphinx pygments tornado requests mock
    - sudo apt-get install pandoc npm
    - sudo npm config set registry http://registry.npmjs.org/
    - sudo npm install casperjs --global
    # Start a virtual desktop for SlimerJS to use.
    - sh -e /etc/init.d/xvfb start
    # Install SlimerJS from GitHub since SlimerJS doesn't have NPM support yet.
    # Pending on: https://github.com/laurentj/slimerjs/issues/64
    - git clone https://github.com/laurentj/slimerjs.git ./slimerjs; cd slimerjs
    - git checkout tags/RELEASE_0.9.0; cd ..
    - sudo ln -s $(pwd)/slimerjs/src/slimerjs /bin/slimerjs
install:
    - python setup.py install -q 
script:
    - cd /tmp && iptest $IPTEST_ARGS

```
@jdfreder I think we can revive this now if you want, and set up a Jenkins job to test it. It needs a rebase, for starters, though.
Rebasing now :)
I think that should do the trick...   Probably a good idea to wait for Travis just in case I missed something in the rebase.
Comments address

OK, I've made jdfreder/ipython#21 against this.

I still see some inconsistent test failures. On my latest run, I got 4:

```
Details for the 4 failed tests:

In /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode.js
  Untitled suite in /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode.js
    assertEquals: initial state; in edit mode
In /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode.js
  Untitled suite in /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode.js
    assertEquals: d, 1 second wait, d doesn't delete a cell
In /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode_arrows.js
  Untitled suite in /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode_arrows.js
    assert: click cell 3; cell 3 is the only cell selected
In /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode_clipboard.js
  Untitled suite in /home/takluyver/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/IPython/html/tests/notebook/dualmode_clipboard.js
    assert: v; cell 3 is the only cell selected
```

> I still see some inconsistent test failures. On my latest run, I got 4:

Those inconsistencies are slimerjs specific, right?

> My guess would be that it's timing issues - I think Slimer is slower. Here are the failures from my latest run:

SlimerJS is definitely much slower, but I thought I nipped all the entry points for timing errors like this in the ~~butt~~ bud.  I'm going to try to replicate these issues you are having, what version of FireFox are you using with SlimerJS?

I'm using Firefox 29. I downloaded the version of Slimer that uses the system installation of Firefox.

...I think the phrase is 'nipped in the bud'. Your version sounds like sexual harassment. ;-)
Haha, yes you are right.  I'm glad GitHub has an edit feature.
The testing machinery looks OK to me now. @jdfreder, any objections to my merging this PR? We can fix up test failures in later PRs.
No objections, go ahead and merge.
